--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> 
> > 
> > In using NEAT, there would only be a trend toward
> > complexification (since NEAT only has additive
> > mutations).  So even if you only used random
> > selection, you would end up with larger, more complex
> > individuals at the end of your run.  They may not be
> > able to *do* anything meaningful, but they would still
> > be significantly different from their ancestors.
> 
> 
> This is not entirely true.  We have actually done this experiment.  
> What NEAT actually does under these conditions is expand its *range*
> of complexity, but the simplest species generally remains intact 
since
> it does just as well as the more complex ones that continue to 
appear.
> It is true that over 500 generations or so the simplest species may
> gain 5 or 10 connections, but this is trivial, since the most 
complex
> species gain hundreds.  

This depends greatly on your parameters, doesn't it?  With smaller 
populations, larger initial genomes, higher mutation rates, and lower 
speciation thresholds, the genetic change from generation to 
generation is going to be more pronounced, isn't it?

> In other words, simplicity is protected in
> NEAT by speciation as long as its competitive, just as complexity is
> protected!

I guess I'm confused about exactly what sort of experiment you're 
referring to.  You say species are protected as long as they're 
competitive, but we were talking about an experiment where no fitness 
function is used.  How would you be "competitive" in a purely random 
selection environment? 

Incidentally, here's a pretty cool little webpage that models 
isolated effects of natural selection and genetic drift.  You can 
pick particular species (e.g. Peppered Moth) and see how the ratio of 
particular genes shifts as a result of either natural selection or 
genetic drift.

http://fmc.utm.edu/~rirwin/NatSelModIntro.htm

Derek
